data.text: Solomon's song of songs.1:1. Each speaker is not explicitly identified in the Hebrew text as shown in this translation, but it is usually clear from the context and gender of the words used who is speaking. Additionally this book is poetry, and therefore translation needs to be more fluid than with prose.

Kiss me, kiss me with your mouth again and again,1:2. Literally, “Let him kiss me with the kisses of his mouth.” The repetition of the word “kiss” forms a superlative, just as “song of songs” really means “the best song.” In addition the poem begins in the third person but then immediately switches to the second person. Such changes are smoothed out for less confusing reading. for your love is sweeter1:2. Literally, “better.” than wine.

I love the way you smell from the perfumed oils you use. You have quite a reputation1:3. Literally, “name.”—it spreads like spilled perfumed oil. It's not surprising that all the young women adore you!

Take me by the hand—let's run! (The king1:4. In love poetry of the time “king” was also a term of endearment. has brought me to his bedroom.) Let's be happy together and find pleasure in your love.1:4. The verb moves to the first person plural, which could mean the change of speaker (some versions believe this line is spoke by the “friends” of the woman). However, it is taken here to be an inclusive form, indicating the woman and the man together. Your love is far better than wine! Women are right to adore you so!1:4. Referring back to the young women of verse 3.

I'm black, but I'm beautiful, women of Jerusalem,1:5. Her dark complexion was an issue for these women of Jerusalem, as it still is in some societies. Accordingly the woman tells them not to look down on her (verse 6). like the tents of Kedar, like the curtains of Solomon.

Don't look down on me because I'm black, because the sun has burned me. My brothers were angry with me and made me look after the vineyards, so I couldn't look after my own vineyard.1:6. In other words, the woman could not look after herself. Note also that in literature of the time, “vineyard” was often used as a fertility metaphor.

My love, please tell me where you're taking your flock. Where will you rest them at noon? For why should I have to wear a veil while looking for you1:7. “Looking for you”: implied. among the flocks of your companions?1:7. The idea seems to be that the woman may have to hide herself during her search if she does not know where her love will be. Some have suggested that wearing a veil in such circumstances may have been like prostitutes who wished to keep their identity secret. Others suggest that the woman thinks other men may be attracted to her and she wishes to avoid that. Yet others suggest emending the text from “wear a veil” to “wander.”
If you really don't know, you who are more beautiful than any other woman, then follow the tracks of my flock, and let your goats graze near the shepherd's tents.

My darling, to me you're like a mare among Pharaoh's horses1:9. To be compared to a horse is not a modern-day complement, but this serves as a reminder that this is a very different culture than today. In addition chariots were pulled by stallions, so there may be some additional meaning here. that pull his chariots,
Your beautiful cheeks adorned with ornaments,1:10. It seems the ornaments the woman is wearing reminds the man of the decorations worn by the chariot horses. your neck with strings of jewels.
Let's make you some gold ornaments inlaid with silver.
As the king lay on his couch, my nard perfume gave off its fragrance.
My love is like a pouch of myrrh,1:13. A perfume placed in a small bag and worn on a string around the neck under clothes. lying all night between my breasts.

My love is like a bunch of fragrant henna flowers in the vineyards of Engedi.1:14. Engedi means “spring of the young goat” and in the context may have a double meaning, together with the “vineyard” symbolism already mentioned.
Look at how very beautiful you are, my darling, how beautiful! Your eyes are as gentle as doves.
And you, my love, are so handsome—how charming you are! The green grass is our bed,
with cedar trees as beams for our “house,” and pine trees for the rafters.
